column2: DOMinate Web Development
What you'll do
Learn about the DOM tree and how to navigate it

Hey, {{user_name}}, the DOM is at the core of how a website is built by the web browser. Mastering the DOM will surely level-up your coding skills by allowing you to customize the look and add cool effects to your website. Let's jump in and unlock the secrets of the DOM!

In your previous HTML and CSS activites, you learned how to style existing tags, and then create your own tags and style those too. All that work you did went into a single HTML file, which the browser reads to create the DOM, and then displayed on your screen.

We’ve created a basic page which you will use to learn about the DOM by adding your favorite things to it. If a window doesn’t open, click on the following link: https://codepen.io/Hack-Computer/pen/WNbpOjV
Think back to the previous HTML lesson and take the first step of personalizing your page by updating the front of the cards. You're going to show off your page, so make it fun!
Look at the HTML window of your Codepen and change the text between <p> and </p> on line 17 to your first favorite thing.

Great! Let's find some images for your site. We'll open another tab for you. If another tab doesn't open, open another tab in your browser and navigate to https://unsplash.com. Find an image you like by using the search bar located at the center of the page. When you find an image you like, right-click on the photo and select Copy image address.

Go back to the HTML section of Codepen and delete the link between the quotation marks on line 17. Paste your new link in between the quotation marks. If you did it right, your new image should appear on the card.
Way to go! Let's personalize the back of the card. Like before, change all of the text between <p> and </p> on lines 20-23 in the HTML section to the reasons why you like this.

Great job! You've personalized the front and back of your first card! Use your mouse and hover over the first card in the blue column to see what you've accomplished. Try personalizing the other eight cards on the page.
Super! As the browser reads your HTML and CSS, it was building all those tags into a structure that looks a lot like an upside-down tree.

Back when Ada was teaching you about the inspector, she walked you through how to view and edit a live website. Whenever you use the Inspector, you're poking around a  representation of the Document Object Model (DOM).
Here is a simplified map of the DOM for this page. Think of it as your treasure map that will lead you to the answer. If a window doesn’t open, click on the following link: http://bit.ly/dommaphack.

Now that you've seen that map, try and see how it lines up with the code in the page your're looking at, showing how all the data is organized. Once you can read a map like this, and understand how the DOM is laid, it makes it a lot easier to do cool things like that card-flipping animation.
OK, let's try something that uses our ability to target specific parts of the page using the DOM. How about changing the color of the text on the front of the first card in the green column?
Now, you could just add some in-line styling, like you did in previous activites, but this time we're going to do it the more advanced way - and you'll see, it actually ends up being easier!
Scroll to the bottom of the CSS section of the CodePen page (it might be minimized, double-click on CSS to open it up), and type in the following text: .green-column .card1 .front p { color: pink }
Nice! Do you see the change on the page? You just turned the text on the front of the first card in the green column into pink text! Do you notice anything interesting about the CSS you typed in?

You probably guessed it already - Those parts with the "." (period) in front of them are being used to "navigate" down through the DOM to end up in a specific part, and that's the part that color: pink gets applied to.
Take another look at the DOM map and see if you can trace the "pathway" your code took.
Now that you've personalized the front of the card, let's try targeting the back of the card so you can personalize it. Take a moment and look at the code. Can you guess how we would go about that?

You probably already guessed it, but we only have to change one term to make the back of the card have pink text as well. Type .green-column .card1 .back p { color: pink } on the line below your previous CSS. The back class you typed is telling the browser to target the back of the card.

Take a look at the back of the card. There are four likes of <p> and one of <h3>. If you have multiple items in a row, like the <p> tags, you can use p:nth-child(somenumber) to target a specific one. Let's color the text of the second <p> by typing the following to your CSS section: .blue-column .card2 .back p:nth-child(2).
Flip the second card in the blue column by hovering over it and notice that the second <p> is now colored orange! Huzzah!

Look at the HTML code for the back of any card. See how the <p> are just below the div? The <div> is the parent of <p> or you can say that the <p> are the child of the div. You can think of the parent as a main branch from the DOM tree and the child as little branches stemming from it.

One final bit. Siblings, who are the immediate stems from the main DOM branch, are all on the same level. For example, all of the cards in the blue columns are siblings of each other, but child of the <div> holding them.

Look at the code for the back of the first card in the orange column. Notice that the <p> and <h3> are both at the same level and in the same <div>, so they are siblings. Type the following to change the styling of the <h3> sibling: .orange-column .card1 .back p + h3 { color: blue }.
Flip the first card in the orange column and you will see that the <h3> will have blue text. Sweet!
What happens if you removed .card1 from the code above? Edit the code and flip over a the cards in the orange column.

Based on how specific you get with your DOM targeting, you can affect one or many elements. Let's try changing the font for the card title of middle card in the green column. Type the following in the CSS window: .green-column .flip:nth-child(2) {font-family: "Comic Sans MS; font-size: 21px;"}.
Great job! Next, remove :nth-child(2) from the code you just typed. You've now changed the CSS to be less specific, so you are now targeting all of card titles in the DOM. CSS is powerful, right?!
